column2: latest Reuters/Ipsos poll finds	"

column1: By Maurice Tamman and Chris Kahn
Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has pulled into an effective tie with Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column2: erasing a substantial deficit as he consolidated support among his party's likely voters in recent weeks
column3: according to the latest Reuters/Ipsos national tracking poll released Friday.The poll showed 40 percent of likely voters supporting Trump and 39 percent backing Clinton for the week of Aug. 26 to Sept. 1. Clinton's support has dropped steadily in the weekly tracking poll since Aug. 25
column4: eliminating what had been a eight-point lead for her.Trump's gains came as Republican support for their party's candidate jumped by six percentage points over the past two weeks
column5: to about 78 percent. That is still below the 85 percent support Republican nominee Mitt Romney enjoyed in the summer of 2012
column6: but the improvement helps explain Trump's rise in the poll.The Reuters/Ipsos poll is conducted online in English in all 50 states. The latest poll surveyed 1
column7: 804 likely voters over the course of the week; it had a credibility interval
column8: a measure of accuracy
column9: of three percent.Different polls have produced widely different results over the course of the campaign. In part that's because some
column11: have attempted to measure the preferences of who's likely to vote
column12: while others have surveyed the larger pool of all registered voters. And even those that survey likely voters have different ways of estimating who is likely to cast a ballot. Polling aggregators
column13: which calculate averages of major polls
column14: have shown that Clinton's lead has been shrinking for the past few weeks. Those averages put her advantage over Trump at between three and six percentage points. Some of the more recent individual polls

column1: Voters don't elect the American president directly
column2: of course
column3: but through the Electoral College
column4: an assembly representing each of the 50 states and the District of Columbia based on the number of legislators they have in Congress. As of last Friday
column5: the separate Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation polling project estimated Clinton was on track to win the Electoral College
column6: by about 332 votes to 206. Those numbers were scheduled to be updated later Friday.In recent weeks
column7: Clinton has come under renewed criticism over her handling of classified information while serving as U.S. secretary of state
column8: and her family's charitable foundation has come under fresh scrutiny for the donations it accepted while Clinton served in the Obama administration. Meanwhile
column9: Clinton hasn't been campaigning as actively as Trump.TRUMP'S BUMP

column1: Trump
column2: meanwhile
column3: has reshuffled his campaign leadership and sought to broaden his appeal to moderate Republicans and minorities. He recently suggested that he would be a better president than Clinton for African Americans
column4: and has taken steps
column5: including a meeting this week with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto
column6: to reach out to immigrants. It remains to be seen whether those efforts will click.Clinton has led Trump through most of the campaign for the November election
column7: though neither candidate appears to have inspired America. In the latest Reuters/Ipsos poll
column8: more than 20 percent of likely voters opted for a choice other than the two major nominees
column9: whether an alternative candidate
column10: ""would not vote"" or ""unsure."" That figure is significantly higher than the 10 percent to 14 percent of respondents who answered similarly at this point in the 2012 campaign. Both President Barack Obama and Republican rival Mitt Romney enjoyed substantially stronger support at this point in the summer of 2012 than either Trump or Clinton does now.

column1: And while Trump has consolidated his support among Republicans
column2: likely voters are expressing an increasingly sour view of Clinton: The share of likely voters with an unfavorable view of the former secretary of state has grown to 57 percent
column3: compared with Trump's 54 percent
column4: her worst showing on that metric in a month.Larry Sabato
column5: director of the University of Virginia Center for Politics
column6: said he remains convinced Clinton is ahead
column7: somewhere in the range seen among the polling aggregators.""There has been a closing that's completely natural
column8: Sabato said. ""Every four years
column9: you have two national party conventions that produce a bounce of varying sizes. Clinton got a substantial bounce this year that lasted for a full month. It's usually gone around Labor Day
column10: and by then we'll be where we should be
column11: which is right around four to five points"" for Clinton.In a separate question in the Reuters/Ipsos poll that included alternative-party candidates
column12: Clinton and Trump were tied at 39 percent. Seven percent supported Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson
column13: and two percent supported Jill Stein of the Green Party. (Edited by Michael Williams)"	['Clinton'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-jersey-taxation-income-idUSKCN1182OZ	New Jersey Governor Christie upends old income tax deal with Pennsylvania	"
By Hilary Russ
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK New Jersey Governor Christie said on Friday the state would begin taxing income earned by people who work in New Jersey but live in Pennsylvania
column2: ending a long-standing arrangement with the neighboring state.Pulling out of the nearly 40-year old ""reciprocity"" agreement would allow New Jersey to raise more revenue starting Jan. 1.Christie
column3: a close ally of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column4: said in a statement that he was forced to act because the Democrat-controlled legislature created a $250 million budget hole in June by relying on public employee health insurance cuts they have not yet made.If lawmakers come back next week and cut health costs
column5: Christie could consider ""revising"" his termination of the reciprocal tax pact.

column1: I will not raise state taxes
column2: cut property tax relief
column3: reduce aid to education or our hospitals
column4: or reduce the state's record pension payment to cover for this blunder by the legislature
column5: Christie said. Jeff Sheridan
column6: press secretary to Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf
column7: said Christie ""erred significantly in his decision to unnecessarily punish 125
column8: 000 Pennsylvanians and cost the commonwealth $5 million annually.""He said Wolf
column9: a Democrat
column10: was hopeful Christie would change his mind. However
column11: Christie seems committed to making Pennsylvania ""suffer the consequences of his failure to enact a responsible budget in a bipartisan way

column1: Pennsylvanians pay a flat 3.07 percent income tax rate with no personal exemptions. New Jerseyans pay higher rates the more they make
column2: with progressive rates increasing from 1.4 percent to 8.97 percent.The reciprocal agreement is advantageous for high-income Pennsylvania residents who work in New Jersey
column3: because they pay their state's lower tax rate. It is also good for low-income New Jerseyans who work across the border because of New Jersey's progressive tax system.

column1: New Jersey Senate President Steve Sweeney said in a statement that ending the scheme is ""the wrong decision for our state"" and that more than 100
column2: 000 New Jersey residents will pay almost $1
column3: 000 per year in additional income tax. ""The burden falls completely on working families in New Jersey
column4: especially those in South Jersey who work in Philadelphia
column5: and will have a very real impact on their quality of life
column6: he said. (Reporting by Hilary Russ; Editing by David Gregorio)"	['Christie']	[]

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-mexico-idUSKCN1182PL	Mexican senator to propose anti-Trump expropriation law	"
By Dave Graham
| MEXICO CITY

MEXICO CITY A Mexican senator is proposing legislation to empower the government to retaliate if a U.S. administration led by Donald Trump inflicts expropriations or economic losses on his country to make it pay for a border wall.Republican presidential nominee Trump has vowed to have Mexico fund the planned wall to keep out illegal immigrants if he is elected
column2: and threatened to fund it by blocking remittances sent home by Mexicans living in the United States.Armando Rios Piter
column3: an opposition senator for the center-left Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD)
column4: will next week present the initiative he hopes will protect Mexicans
column5: and highlight the risks of targeting them economically.The plan offers a taste of the kind of tit-for-tat measures that could gain traction between the two heavily-integrated economies if Trump wins the presidency at the Nov. 8 election.In a preliminary summary of the proposal
column6: which also foresees giving the Senate the power to disavow international treaties when the interests of Mexico or its companies are threatened by other signatories
column7: it states:

column1: In cases where the property/assets of (our) fellow citizens or companies are affected by a foreign government
column2: as Donald Trump has threatened
column3: the Mexican government should proportionally expropriate assets and properties of foreigners from that country on our territory.""Total remittances to Mexico from abroad - most of which come from the United States - were worth nearly $25 billion last year
column4: according to the central bank. Bilateral trade between the two nations is worth about half a trillion dollars a year.Trump has also threatened to tear up a trade deal with Mexico if it is not recast in the United States' favor. He met President Enrique Pena Nieto in Mexico City this week
column5: sparking fierce criticism in Mexico of the government for hosting him.

column1: Afterwards
column2: Trump repeated his pledge to make Mexico foot the bill for the wall. Mexico says it will not pay.It is yet to be established how such expropriations could work
column3: nor is it clear what chance the bill could have of passing. The PRD and other leftist parties hold less than a quarter of the 128 seats in Mexico's Senate.

column1: Rios Piter said his aim was to counter threats by Trump to target Mexicans in the United States and to stress that the economic welfare of both nations is at stake.""At a time like this
column2: it's vital for us to understand why this relationship benefits both. We're neighbors
column3: we're friends
column4: we're partners
column5: he said. ""He's putting (that) at risk.""The initiative also seeks to protect Mexico against unilateral changes to the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)
column6: which Trump has threatened to ditch. (Editing by Alistair Bell)"	['Trump']	[]

WASHINGTON/NEW YORK Hillary Clinton said on Friday that if elected to the White House she would create an oversight panel to protect U.S. consumers from large price hikes on long-available
column2: lifesaving drugs and to import alternative treatments if necessary

column4: the Democratic presidential candidate

column10: life-saving treatments with little or no new innovation or R&D
column11: Clinton said in a statement.If Clinton defeats Republican rival Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election
column12: she would need the support of the U.S. Congress to implement key measures of her proposal
column13: which follows a broader plan to rein in drug prices that she announced a year ago.Even though her latest plan would likely affect a small number of companies

column16: adding that a ""Republican Congress would push back hard on this.""Clinton's campaign cited Turing Pharmaceuticals LLC's raising the price of its AIDS drug Daraprim (pyrimethamine) and Mylan NV's repeated steep price increases on EpiPen for severe allergy sufferers as ""troubling"" examples of price hikes that have attracted bipartisan congressional scrutiny.Conover said Clinton's plan to address unjustified price hikes is less of a concern to the drug industry than her pledge last year to reduce drug prices overall.Drugmakers have said that lowering or limiting drug prices would hamper their ability to invest in research and lead to fewer new therapies.The ARCA Pharmaceutical Index of large U.S. and European drugmakers rose 0.30 percent on Friday
column17: in line with gains for the broad stock market. Shares of Mylan fell 4.6 percent to $40.00 on the Nasdaq.

column6: and then hiked its price by 5
column7: 000 percent. Soon afterward
column8: Clinton presented a general plan to lower prescription drug costs
column9: including allowing Medicare to negotiate drug prices and demand higher rebates for prescription drugs. Her plan would also include caps on monthly and annual out-of-pocket costs for patients with chronic or serious health conditions. It aims to prohibit manufacturers from paying generic drugmakers to delay launching their cheaper products
column10: and would eliminate corporate writeoffs for direct-to-consumer pharmaceutical advertising.A ""BOLD IDEA""

column8: head of political analysis for Evercore ISI
column9: said Clinton's proposed panel had little hope of getting through Congress.

column2: if elected

column8: Haines said shares of pharmaceutical and biotech companies could come ""under sustained headline risk in 2017 as ACA reforms are discussed.""        In cases where a price hike determined to be unjustified is accompanied by insufficient market competition

column10: an associate professor at Harvard Medical School

column14: Kesselheim said.""Having the government get involved as a long-term purchaser of these products creates a stockpile to stabilize the market
column15: he said.Kesselheim has testified before Congress about high-cost generic and long-available drugs and spoke to Clinton's campaign about his research as it developed its proposals. (Reporting by Amanda Becker in Washington; and Ransdell Pierson in New York; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Leslie Adler)"	['Clinton'

By Scott Malone
| BOSTON

BOSTON (Editor's note: This story contains language in the second paragraph that may offend readers)The president of Maine's state Senate on Friday said he would not pursue a special session to censure Governor Paul LePage for leaving a profanity-laden voicemail message for a lawmaker amid a dispute about the governor's comments on race and drug dealing.Senator Michael Thibodeau
column2: who like LePage is a Republican

column4: socialist cocksucker.""But on Friday he said he would not follow the lead of state House Speaker Mark Eves
column5: who began polling lawmakers in his chamber as to whether they were ready to call a special session ""to take action regarding the Governor's conduct.""

column1: He is unfit to serve as Governor and must resign or be removed from office
column2: Eves said of LePage in a statement on Friday.That query
column3: Thibodeau said
column4: went further than Senate Republicans were willing to go
column5: adding that his party had been ready to vote for a one-day session to vote on an official censure of LePage
column6: whose current term extends through 2018.""We're not interested in coming back for impeachment
column7: Thibodeau told reporters.

column1: The state House and Senate both adjourned in April and are not due to meet again until after the November elections.LePage has faced a flurry of criticism over the past week for saying that members of minority groups from out of state were responsible for the lion's share of the heroin trade in Maine. He drew further criticism after leaving a profane and widely circulated voicemail for a lawmaker that he believed had called him a racist.
Earlier in the week he mused during a 15-minute radio interview about the idea of not finishing out his term
column2: only to come back a day later to say that he would not resign.Earlier this year a group of lawmakers started an effort to impeach him
column3: contending the governor overstepped his authority by threatening to withhold funds from a nonprofit group that hired a political rival
column4: but that effort collapsed before making it to the full House.Under Maine's constitution
column5: Thibodeau would have been first in line to succeed LePage if he stepped down or was removed from office. (Reporting by Scott Malone; Editing by James Dalgleish)"	['Paul'

Many of the positions involved might typically come with six-figure annual paychecks in other campaigns.""It's unprecedented for a presidential campaign to rely so heavily on volunteers for top management positions

column9: Matt Rhoades
column13: have not been paid include finance chairman Steven Mnuchin

column17: knocking on voters' doors and passing out campaign buttons. There are instances in other campaigns of senior staff opting not to draw a paycheck. For example

column20: considers his role honorary and does not draw a salary.

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-foundation-idUSKCN1182E9	State Department vetted Bill Clintonâ€™s contacts

column1: By Emily Stephenson and Mark Hosenball
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The Clinton Foundation on multiple occasions during Hillary Clinton's tenure as secretary of state asked senior U.S. government officials to vet her husband's contacts with potentially controversial international figures
column2: according to emails released by the State Department.The emails
column3: reviewed by Reuters
column4: were part of a batch of nearly 400 messages recently released by the State Department after requests from the conservative group Citizens United
column5: a group that has long been critical of the Clintons.The exchanges show a top foreign policy adviser to the foundation sought guidance from the State Department on former President Bill Clinton's interactions with people including Syrian President Bashar al-Assad
column6: Russian government officials and business leaders
column7: and Gulnara Karimova
column8: the socialite daughter of Uzbekistan's late president.The emails offer a glimpse of the intricate relationship between a private charity with a broad global mission and the State Department under the leadership of a secretary who is married to a former president.Former government officials reached by Reuters said there was nothing inappropriate in the interactions of the foundation with the State Department over the potential meetings
column9: some of which did not occur.The latest batch of emails likely represents only a partial view of all the exchanges between the State Department and the foundation. It is unclear how frequently the foundation sought advice from the State Department on meetings involving Bill Clinton.In one instance
column11: a foreign policy adviser to the foundation and to Bill Clinton
column12: raised the possibility in 2009 of a meeting between Bill Clinton and Syrian President Assad. At the time
column13: Assad wanted better ties with the West.""Would this be concerning for State?"" Desai wrote in an email alerting Hillary Clinton aide Jake Sullivan to the possible meeting.

column1: The Syrians expressed a keen interest in facilitating this
column2: Desai said in an email a few days later.The Syria visit was proposed to be tacked onto a forum Bill Clinton was invited to attend in Israel in November 2009
column3: according to the emails. The meeting never happened
column4: according to Martin Indyk
column5: a former U.S. ambassador to Israel who helped  to organize the trip.The State Department sometimes communicates with charities
column6: such as about circumstances that might involve the safety of Americans or highly sensitive diplomatic situations
column7: but it typically does not vet their contacts with foreign leaders to this extent. State Department spokesman Elizabeth Trudeau said officials occasionally provide talking points and briefings to ex-presidents.Much of Bill Clinton's communications with the State Department stemmed from an ethics agreement that was put in place when Hillary Clinton became secretary of state in 2009. The agreement was aimed at avoiding conflicts of interests stemming from contributions to the foundation and Bill Clinton's paid speeches and consulting. Trudeau said these were ""voluntary steps"" taken to avoid ""even the appearance of a conflict of interest.""Angel Urena
column8: press secretary for Bill Clinton
column9: said the requests for State Department input on potential meetings
column10: talking points and other information ""was done in order to inform the administration of President Clinton's interactions with foreign governments and dignitaries
column11: so that the administration could in turn offer advice or voice any concerns."" Urena said Bill Clinton had sought advice on his activities since he left office in 2001.

column1: The Clinton Foundation referred questions to Urena. Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign declined to comment.CHARITY QUESTIONS LINGER
Clinton's campaign to win the Nov. 8 presidential election has been dogged by criticism of the Bill
column2: Hillary & Chelsea Clinton Foundation
column3: a global philanthropic organization.

column1: The foundation has said it will stop accepting at least some foreign and corporate donations if Hillary Clinton becomes president and that Bill Clinton would resign from the foundation's board.In one previously unreported email exchange
column2: Desai wrote to the State Department in May 2012 informing officials that Bill Clinton would travel to Monaco to raise money for the foundation at an event where he might cross paths with the elder daughter of the Uzbekistan president.Gulnara Karimova
column3: a businesswoman and pop star
column4: was described in a 2005 cable from a U.S. embassy official as the ""single most hated person in Uzbekistan"" because of her flamboyant lifestyle in an authoritarian country. She has since come under investigation in an international bribery scandal.Ahead of the event in Monaco
column5: Desai wrote that the organizers had invited Karimova to be one of the event's sponsors ""apparently without our approval.""The Uzbekistan president's daughter ""will be listed in the program and will see (Bill Clinton)
column6: he said. ""Would (the U.S. government) have concerns? If so
column7: we can go back to organizer and ask them to return her sponsorship and disinvite her
column8: however I assume that would ruffle some feathers
column9: Desai said.The emails released to Citizens United don't contain a reply to Desai's inquiry. However
column10: a collection of photos from the Monaco event posted on the internet show Karimova attended it. They do not show any pictures of her with Bill Clinton. (Editing by Caren Bohan and Edward Tobin)"	['Sullivan'

column8: U.S. Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia
column9: the commission said. C-SPAN's Steve Scully will be a back-up moderator for all four of the debates
column12: has said he will take part in the three debates but wants to see the conditions. Representatives for the Trump campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Friday's announcement.

column1: The New York businessman
column2: who has never held elected office
column3: has had repeated run-ins with the media since launching his campaign last year
column4: charging networks like CNN with ""phony reporting
column5: sparring with MSNBC hosts and insulting Fox News journalist Megyn Kelly. His campaign has also black-listed several reporters and news outlets.Clinton
column6: the Democratic candidate
column7: has said she will participate in all three debates as scheduled. Separately
column8: NBC has said Trump and Clinton will participate in a ""commander-in-chief"" forum focused on military issues on Sept. 7 in New York
column9: appearing separately.

column1: On Friday
column2: Trump's son Eric raised questions about ties between the anchor for that event
column3: Matt Lauer
column4: and the Clinton Foundation and said NBC and its cable offshoot MSNBC have been against his father.""Obviously
column5: there's a lot of speculation because of his involvement with the foundation

column1: Representatives for NBC said Lauer was not a member of the foundation and that he had interviewed former President Bill Clinton for the network's ""Today"" show

column3: ""The Apprentice
column4: debuted on NBC in 2004. NBC later cut other ties with the businessman

column6: and Trump sued.NBC is a unit of Comcast Corp.. Fox News is part of the Twenty-First Century Fox Inc

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN1175BU	Hispanic backers sour on Trump after immigration speech	"
By Emily Stephenson and Amanda Becker
| WILMINGTON
column2: Ohio/WASHINGTON

column1: WILMINGTON
column2: Ohio/WASHINGTON Some of Donald Trump's Hispanic backers distanced themselves from the Republican nominee on Thursday for standing by a hardline approach to illegal immigration in a key speech after indicating for weeks that he may soften his approach.Trump tried to clarify confusion about immigration
column3: his signature policy issue
column4: in a speech on Wednesday. He said the only way undocumented foreigners could live in the United States legally if he is elected on Nov. 8 would be to leave the country and apply for re-entry.But the businessman
column5: trailing Democratic rival Hillary Clinton in opinion polls
column6: did back away from earlier promises to deport immediately the 11 million immigrants in the United States illegally and said he would prioritize those with criminal records.While polls show a large majority of Hispanic voters oppose Trump
column7: the withdrawal of support from among his small group of Latino backers underscores how difficult it is for Trump to broaden his support with minorities and moderate voters.    Alfonso Aguilar
column8: who recently organized a support letter on behalf of Trump
column9: said he felt ""disappointed and misled"" by the fiery speech and withdrew his backing. ""For the last two months he said he was not going to deport people without criminal records. He actually said that he was going to treat undocumented immigrants without criminal records in a humane and compassionate way
column10: Aguilar told CNN. He is the president of the Latino Partnership for Conservative Principles group.  Trump used his Wednesday appearance in Phoenix to clarify his stance on illegal immigration. But instead of moderating his message as many expected
column11: Trump returned to the hardline rhetoric that powered him to victory in the Republican presidential nomination race over 16 rivals
column12: heartening conservatives drawn to Trump by the issue.      Some members of a council Trump formed last month to advise him on Hispanic issues expressed reservations about or cut ties to the New York real estate developer's candidacy after the Phoenix speech.

column1: Jacob Monty
column2: a Texas attorney and member of the group
column3: said he was withdrawing his support and would not vote in the election.""There was nothing pro-business in that speech
column4: Monty told MSNBC. ""We were hoping for some glimmer of the Donald Trump that we met with a week and half ago
column5: but it never came.""""SCAM""

column1: Panel member Ramiro Pena
column2: a Baptist pastor in Texas who spoke at the Republican National Convention in July
column3: wrote in an email to party leaders that he believed Trump would lose the election and that the advisory panel was a ""scam.""

column1: But other Latino advisers
column2: including Florida pastor Mario Bramnick and Kentucky State Senator Ralph Alvardo
column3: said they would continue working with the Trump campaign.Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus downplayed the fallout from Trump's speech
column4: telling CNN that the nominee made clear he first wants to build the border wall and deal with criminal elements
column5: then have a ""humane conversation"" about other illegal immigrants.""Somehow or another no one is talking about that piece
column6: Priebus said. At a campaign rally on Thursday in Wilmington
column7: Ohio
column8: Trump said his immigration plan would treat everyone with ""dignity
column9: respect and compassion"" but prioritize compassion for American citizens and include some kind of ideological screening.

column1: We only want to admit those into our country who share our values and love our people
column2: Trump said.     Trump gave his Phoenix address
column3: which was flagged as a major policy speech
column4: just hours after he met with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto in Mexico City. At a joint press conference after the meeting
column5: Trump said the pair discussed his campaign promise to build a border wall but not which country would pay for it. Pena Nieto said on Twitter on Wednesday night he had ""made it clear"" Mexico would not be paying for the wall.Trump supporters at the Wilmington rally said they approved of the candidate's immigration policies but moderate Republicans in Arizona
column6: where Latinos make up more than 30 percent of the population
column7: told Reuters they were less swayed by his message.Clinton's campaign called Trump's immigration speech a ""disaster"" and said it would begin running advertisements in Arizona
column8: a sign it sees a chance of winning a state that has long backed Republican presidential candidates.Clinton raised about $143 million in August for her presidential bid and the Democratic Party
column9: her campaign announced. Trump has not yet released his fundraising totals for the month of August.     (Additional reporting by Steve Holland
column10: Susan Heavey and David Alexander in Washington and Emily Flitter in New York; Editing by Alistair Bell and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Aguilar'
